prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Physical conditions in the HD142527 dust trap
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Detect molecular decrements in emission, sample kinematics of CO-depleted regions.
The main purpose of this science goal is to test if the molecular decrements seen under the horseshoe of HD142527 are indeed due to a lack of gas-phase CO.
We are also acquiring band 7 continuum for measuring grain growth, in conjunction with Science Goal `Grain Growth'.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As explained in the science case, the sensitivity requirement is driven by the previous detection of H2CO. We assumed that the outer disk morphology in H2CO290.6GHz is similar to that seen in HCO+ in our Cycle0 data. Then, we fit a non-parametric MEM model to the HCO+ visibilities, thus obtaining a deconvolved model of the HCO+ distribution, which we used as a proxy for H2CO. We scaled the total flux of this H2CO proxy by the ratio of the integrated flux, so that the total flux in the H2CO proxy is equal to 2 Jy km/s. simobserve simulating and CASA clean gives a peak H2CO flux of 12mJy/beam, which drops to 3mJy/beam near the decrements. Since we want to test for the absence of decrements, a noise of 3mJy/beam at 0.5km/s is enough, and will also allow us to test for velocity dispersion trends (in Cycle0 CO21 we saw an increase of 0.9 to 1.5km/s).
The high data rate is unavoidable as we need to measure several lines to 1- try to detect all gas-phase tracers in CO-depleted environments, so the 3 lines of N2H+, DCO+ and H2CO, and 2- sample temperature and density diagnostics.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cavity dynamics
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The purpose of this science goal is to find structure along the Cycle0 filaments inside the HD142527, seen in HCO+(4-3). We also need to

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The integration time is driven by our previous detection of the HCO+(4-3) filaments. We simulated Cycle2 observations with simobserve, using as input a deconvolved data cube for HCO+(4-3). The resulting intensity levels along the filaments, in systemic velocity, are 15~mJy/beam. We are aiming for a 3 sigma detection at a sufficiently fine spectral resolution so as to detect possible HCO+ knots in Keplerian rotation about a compact object (with planetary-mass parameters, so linewidths of about 0.9km/s which we need to resolve, hence the choice of 0.2km/s sensitivity bandwidth.
Data Rate: we need the HCO+ and CO lines, and have place a continuum spectral window to sample the grain opacities, as explained in the science case. The HCN is imporant also - we have detected this specie (van der Plas et al. 2014), and it shows strong decrements under the horseshoe and also shows a hint for a counterpart of the HCO$^+$ flows (albeit not as bright).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Grain growth
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The purpose of this `science goal' is to acquire deep continua at low ALMA frequency, with frequency leverage to sample opacity and spectral index variations.
We demonstrate feasibility in the science case by producing an opacity map fit the the Cycle0 band7 basebands. We can include inter-band data in the fit by relying on very accurate total flux calibration tied to the observed spectral energy distribution, and with flux-loss estimates calibrated on disk models.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The integration time is driven by our previous detection of the HCO+(4-3) filaments. We simulated Cycle2 observations with simobserve, using as input a deconvolved data cube for HCO+(4-3). The resulting intensity levels along the filaments, in systemic velocity, are 15~mJy/beam. We are aiming for a 3 sigma detection at a sufficiently fine spectral resolution so as to detect possible HCO+ knots in Keplerian rotation about a compact object (with planetary-mass parameters, so linewidths of about 0.9km/s which we need to resolve, hence the choice of 0.2km/s sensitivity bandwidth.
Data Rate: we need the HCO+ and CO lines, and have place a continuum spectral window to sample the grain opacities, as explained in the science case. The HCN is imporant also - we have detected this specie (van der Plas et al. 2014), and it shows strong decrements under the horseshoe and also shows a hint for a counterpart of the HCO$^+$ flows (albeit not as bright).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Velocity dispersion in the horseshoe
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The purpose of this `science goal' is to measure the kinematics of the CO decrements. In Perez et al. (2014) we report that the CO(2-1) line is broader under the CO(2-1) decrements than in the rest of the horseshoe, from 0.9 to 1.4km/s.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The deconvolved Cycle0 data (obtained with MEM modelling) provide a proxy for the intensity distribution of CO(2-1) in the outer disk of HD142527, where we need to sample kinematics. Thus we simulated Cycle observations using simobserve on the HCO+ models, and scaled the results by the ratio of integrated fluxes. The resulting intensity levels under the region of interest is 20mJy/beam, which we need to detect at 3sigma and sample at 0.1km/s in order to confirm the velocity dispersion trends seen in our Cycle0 data.
We centred a continuum band around Ha30, this is a fiducial frequency served mainly to define the continuum position.
Data Rate: we need to observe in CO isotopologues to constrain the gas opacity above the molecular decrements.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
According to recent theoretical progress, the clearing of the protoplanetary cavity by an accreting gaseous giant should lead to apressure enhancement in the outer rim of the gap, shaped into a horseshoe, where dust grains are trapped, and where temperatures drop. Core-accretion may occur efficiently in these dust traps, leading to second generation planet formation. In this scenario the origin of the outer disk pressure enhancement is due to on-going dynamical clearing. Inside the gap, the first generation giant(s) channel outer disk material across the gap, thus feeding stellar accretion.
The HD142527 disk is an ideal laboratory to test the scenario of second generation core accretion at large stellocentric radii. It hosts the best-studied horse-shoe and the largest cavity in a face-on orientation, in which gas kinematics have been resolved in Cycle0. We aim to 1- measure grain growth inside the dust trap of HD142527, 2- measure physical conditions and kinematics in the dust trap, and 3- understand the cavity dynamics to ascertain the physical origin of the gap-crossing flows.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
